content.raw:
This model can simulate Real Nao Robot well, except that it has two hip yaw joints instead of one hip yaw joint the real NAO has. the only critical issue related to this model is its Maximum joints effort which is reported in issue #6. The effort value is too low, if you compare to other Humanoid SDF model e.g. different version of atlas models that can be found in this [link](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim) which for example there these <effort> values are between 200 to 800 and in this model they are between 1 to 3. I think it is not possible to control the dynamics of a NAO robot with these low effector values.

According to modeling robocup NAO type zero, which is oldest and most common robot model used in the simsperk, this model can not simulate that robot, because of the differences in joint configuration, limitations and some minor links dimension and mass. I think we can keep this model as it is for the researchers that are interested to have Aldebaran NAO robot in this simulator. As a model to be used in RoboCup we should bridge the gap of the Aldebaran NAO model and robocup model. Actually Aldebaran NAO model can not be used in simulation league with this specification since it is not powerful enough to play in such a big field.  Recently I could model the joint of  robocup NAO type Zero and test it with the robocup agents. In rev. 94bbbd7 the Robocup NAO model has been uploaded.
content.html:
This model can simulate Real Nao Robot well, except that it has two hip yaw joints instead of one hip yaw joint the real NAO has. the only critical issue related to this model is its Maximum joints effort which is reported in issue #6. The effort value is too low, if you compare to other Humanoid SDF model e.g. different version of atlas models that can be found in this link which for example there these <effort> values are between 200 to 800 and in this model they are between 1 to 3. I think it is not possible to control the dynamics of a NAO robot with these low effector values.

According to modeling robocup NAO type zero, which is oldest and most common robot model used in the simsperk, this model can not simulate that robot, because of the differences in joint configuration, limitations and some minor links dimension and mass. I think we can keep this model as it is for the researchers that are interested to have Aldebaran NAO robot in this simulator. As a model to be used in RoboCup we should bridge the gap of the Aldebaran NAO model and robocup model. Actually Aldebaran NAO model can not be used in simulation league with this specification since it is not powerful enough to play in such a big field. Recently I could model the joint of robocup NAO type Zero and test it with the robocup agents. In rev. 94bbbd7 the Robocup NAO model has been uploaded.

content.html: nima, can you create a pull request into this branch to merge the type 0 nao file?

content.html: It can be a separate pull request to default be more compact

content.raw:
Thanks a lot for looking into this, @nima_sh .  Feel free to make a pull request with the type zero robot. I would recommend putting it in another directory, with its own `model.config` and `model.sdf` files, so it is consistent with the model database structure. This way, both the "real" NAO and the type zero will show up on the left Insert tab. It can still use the same meshes for visuals if you want, you just need to specify it in the uri.

As for the `HipYaw` joint, we could either leave it like this for now or try an adventure with gearbox joints ;)
content.html:
Thanks a lot for looking into this, @nima_sh . Feel free to make a pull request with the type zero robot. I would recommend putting it in another directory, with its own model.config and model.sdf files, so it is consistent with the model database structure. This way, both the "real" NAO and the type zero will show up on the left Insert tab. It can still use the same meshes for visuals if you want, you just need to specify it in the uri.

As for the HipYaw joint, we could either leave it like this for now or try an adventure with gearbox joints ;)
